channel.title: Comments on: Manipulating data like a boss with d3

item.title: By: Carlos Ayres
item.dc:creator: Carlos Ayres
item.description: Yes, an old post, but still excelent. Thanks for sharing
item.content:encoded: Yes, an old post, but still excelent. Thanks for sharing

item.title: By: Mohammad Alshafey
item.dc:creator: Mohammad Alshafey
item.description:
Many tutorials about how to use json or csv with d3.json or d3.csv, but the simplest idea of using an array or data object is still a mystery...
For simple applications, updating a json or csv file dynamically is a nightmare. Being able to load an object with the needed data dynamically should be simple, darn it!
item.content:encoded:
Many tutorials about how to use json or csv with d3.json or d3.csv, but the simplest idea of using an array or data object is still a mystery…

For simple applications, updating a json or csv file dynamically is a nightmare. Being able to load an object with the needed data dynamically should be simple, darn it!

item.title: By: You may not need d3 | Jerome Cukier

item.title: By: Resources for using multiple graphs in D3.js, from #knightD3 teachers / students | Drawing the Data
item.dc:creator: Resources for using multiple graphs in D3.js, from #knightD3 teachers / students | Drawing the Data

item.title: By: Steve Bennett
item.dc:creator: Steve Bennett
item.description:
Hey, thanks for the tutorial. I was a bit put off by the 3 caveats, but they're actually much more minor than you make them sound:
1. A really easy way to make something run on a webserver is using site44 - host the files from your dropbox. 2. Not sure I understand this one. Just define a global variable, then assign values to it in the callback. 3. Yep.
item.content:encoded:
Hey, thanks for the tutorial. I was a bit put off by the 3 caveats, but they’re actually much more minor than you make them sound:

1. A really easy way to make something run on a webserver is using site44 – host the files from your dropbox.
2. Not sure I understand this one. Just define a global variable, then assign values to it in the callback.
3. Yep.

item.title: By: Emesh
item.dc:creator: Emesh
item.description: Hi Jerome, I am very new to D3.js, currently i was working on a school project using d3 and json. Your tutorial was very helpful so i decide to implement it in my project since it the nested data its much more similar to mine even though mine is json file . at the moment it groups the data correctly unfortunately the individual data which is represented by the circle faille to work. i was wondering what went wrong, I really appreciate it if you can take a look at it. here is the link to the project (https://github.com/emesh/IPU-Zabbix-D3) Thanks in advance!!
item.content:encoded:
Hi Jerome,
I am very new to D3.js, currently i was working on a school project using d3 and json. Your tutorial was very helpful so i decide to implement it in my project since it the nested data its much more similar to mine even though mine is json file . at the moment it groups the data correctly unfortunately the individual data which is represented by the circle faille to work. i was wondering what went wrong, I really appreciate it if you can take a look at it.
here is the link to the project (https://github.com/emesh/IPU-Zabbix-D3)
Thanks in advance!!

item.title: By: jerome
item.dc:creator: jerome
item.description: well, the name of the attributes would come from your data file. so this assumes that you know your data file. that being said, for any element of the array, you can do d3.keys() which will return the list of properties of that element. ie d3.keys(csv[0]).
item.content:encoded:
well, the name of the attributes would come from your data file. so this assumes that you know your data file.
that being said, for any element of the array, you can do d3.keys() which will return the list of properties of that element. ie d3.keys(csv[0]).

item.title: By: jerome
item.dc:creator: jerome
item.description: i can't be definitive without seeing your data file but mostly, do you define your line function somewhere?
item.content:encoded: i can’t be definitive without seeing your data file but mostly, do you define your line function somewhere?

item.title: By: maadso
item.dc:creator: maadso
item.content:encoded:
Hi Jerome,

Great tutorial, this was super helpful for my entrance into d3 with csvs! I’m trying to make a line chart with date as the x-axis, sum of orders as the y-axis, and a line/color for each of my three stores. My dataset has a row for each order, so I need to sum the order by date and store:

d3.csv(file, function(error, data) {

color.domain(d3.keys(data[0]).filter(function(key) { return key == “store”; }));

data = data.map( function (d) {
return {
store: d.store,
date: parseDate(d.date),
orders: +d.orders };
});

data = d3.nest()
.key(function(d) {return d.date;})
.sortKeys(d3.ascending)
.key(function(d) { return d.store; })
.sortKeys(d3.ascending)
.rollup(function(d) {
return {
orders: d3.sum(d,function(t) {return +t.orders;})
};
}).entries(data);

I keep getting an error at this line in the code, and though the axis are drawn on the page, there is no data:

store.append(“path”)
.attr(“class”, “line”)
.attr(“d”, function(d) { console.log(d);return line(d.values); })
.style(“stroke”, function(d) { return color(d.key); });

Can you offer any insight? Thanks in advance!
